ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was not very familiar with the PLSC department before this course. This seminar introduced me to the various techniques and fields of political science and allowed me to make relevant and eye opening connections between current events and theory. I gained a more clear-eyed view of social movements I had already known about or had been involved in, and the course also introduced me to many groups, events, and movements I had not heard of.
I gained knowledge of the structural conditions that influence the emergence, sustenance, and decline of social movement organizations.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The seminar, discussion-based format of this course was very conducive to a lively and in depth dialogue throughout the course. We grew as a class together, guided by professor Hierro. There was a wonderful variety of material from readings in theory, scientific studies, documentaries, news articles and guest speakers who were leaders in their respective fields. I appreciated the thought provoking assignments which prepared us for class and allowed us to reflect on previous discussions. Overall, this was a very well designed and executed course.

The course readings, semi-lecture format, and group discussions were enriching. The guest lectures were also very informative and help to elucidate and reinforce the course themes. Lastly, Professor Hierro was very charismatic, accessible, and create an environment that facilitated learning, revision, and shared dialogue.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Even though I'm not a Political Science major, this course was fascinating to me and has been a joy to be a part of. The classes moved by very quickly, and professor Hierro cultivated a welcoming and impressive intellectual environment. I felt that my classmates and I were really working together in discussions to obtain a deep understanding of the material in a way which was both fun and satisfying.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. The course readings, semi-lecture format, and group discussions were enriching. I gained knowledge of the structural conditions that influence the emergence, sustenance, and decline of social movement organizations. The guest lectures were also very informative and help to elucidate and reinforce the course themes. Lastly, Professor Hierro was very charismatic, accessible, and create an environment that facilitated learning, revision, and shared dialogue.

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.
How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: I have already seen my classmates implement the skills and ideas we discussed in this course in real-life scenarios. I gained perspectives on both the macro and micro workings of political movements in the context of a wide variety of formations, geographical locations, tactics, and end results. Not only are these tools helpful in my own analysis of past movements, but they allow me to be more critically engaged in current issues that I care about.

I will use the political science frameworks (political opportunity structures, theories of collective action, strategic complementarity vs. substitutability, mobilizing strategies via appeal to emotions, threats, etc., resource mobilization) to analyze historical, contemporary, and future protests along with other social and political phenomena (i.e. voting). I will also use these insights to guide and inform my personal social justice activism.
